results:
Based on the search results, I found valuable information about Polish literary criticism and interpretations of "The Sorrows of Young Werther" (Cierpienia młodego Wertera), particularly focusing on Tadeusz Żeleński-Boy's interpretations.

## Key Findings:

### Tadeusz Boy-Żeleński's Interpretation

Tadeusz Boy Żeleński presented a different interpretation of this romantic work. In his reading, the focus shifts from romantic love that led to the hero's death to social problems in which Werther was entangled. It seems that Boy negated the entire idea of romantic love in favor of a Marxist theory about class struggle, in whose gears the individual undergoes great pressures.(no content)Boy-Żeleński's essay titled "I Read 'Werther'" (Czytałem "Wertera") was included in a volume of critical works with the significant title "Literary Provocations" (Literackie prowokacje). Its content truly treats Romantic literature with Boy's characteristic wink, which, given the monumental character of great works of this period, had to be considered a provocation.

### Boy's Main Arguments

Żeleński points out the mistaken, "bronze-coating" reading of "Werther" that has become established in literary culture over many years of repeating the same, stereotypical analyses of Goethe's novel mainly as a sentimental romance. Meanwhile - as Boy observes with his characteristic insight - the hero of this work actually chooses suffering for himself, dramatizing an innocent crush on a young lady.(no content)Boy believes that it wasn't romantic love and the attitude of a romantic hero that influenced Werther's decision, but social problems. He considers that social problems were the main cause of death of this young, very emotional person. My opinion is completely different, as I believe that the main cause of Werther's suicide was unrequited love.

### Polish Critical Reception

These two readings of Goethe's work - Boy's reading and the romantic reading - are essentially equally valid. This stems from the fact that we cannot say Boy was wrong in his observations, especially since he was a great connoisseur of literature. It is rather a matter of views on literature. Everyone can read and interpret a book as they wish, as long as they support it with appropriate arguments. Therefore, Boy's reading is controversial, but no less true than the romantic one, because a literary text does not have one proper interpretation and that is the greatest power of literature.

### Contemporary Polish Literary Discourse

The search results show that Boy's interpretation continues to generate discussion in Polish literary criticism. In his essay, Boy realizes the path he established at the beginning of his journalistic career - "de-bronzing" both great literary authorities and themes repeated so often and for so long in mistaken interpretation that their vision takes root too deeply for the reader to make the effort of independent, exploratory search for proper meanings.

The debate between Boy's sociological interpretation and the traditional romantic reading remains a significant topic in Polish literary studies, with students and scholars continuing to engage with both perspectives when analyzing Goethe's influential work.
